title: Two Scottish men charged in connection with Metropolitan Police hack
text:
These posts appeared on the Met’s Twitter account earlier this year (Image: Twitter)

Two men have been arrested in charged and connection with the hack of a Metropolitan Police website and social media account.

In July this year, a series of bizarre messages appeared on the force’s Twitter account and fake press releases were posted on its webpage.

One message called for the release of drill rap artist Digga D, who was believed to be in prison at the time, saying: ‘‘FREE DIGGA D ON FOENEM GANG.’

Another said ‘ ‘F**K THE POLICE FREE DA GANG’

There were also several men’s names mentioned in the tweets and press releases.

Digga D is a drill rapper from London who is believed to have been imprisoned earlier this year (Image: Twitter)

A screenshot of tweets from the Met’s Twitter account saying ‘f**k the police’ (Picture: Twitter)

The Met Police said attackers managed to gain access to a service called MyNewsDesk, which manages the publication of press releases.

At the time, the attack was blamed on a gang of teenage cyber-vandals from the US.

The two men who have been charged are aged 18 and 19.

They are both from Scotland, with one living in Lossiemouth in the northeast and the other in Glasgow.

President Donald Trump retweeted one of Katie Hopkins’ posts about the hacks (Image: Twitter)

A Police Scotland spokesperson told Metro: ‘Two men, aged 18 and 19, from the Lossiemouth and Glasgow areas respectively, have been arrested and charged in connection with unauthorised access and publication of content on the Metropolitan Police Service’s news platform on Friday 19 July 2019.’

“A report will be submitted to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service.’

We discussed the hacks with London-based cybersecurity expert Chris Monteiro, who said: ‘Whoever carried out the attacks could have made all kinds of money had they pushed something like “Boris Johnson under investigation” with political betting or corporate markets.

‘This shows it was opportunistic, or amateurish, or both.’

He said the attack highlighted ‘bad security practice’ at the Metropolitan Police.
description: Bizarre messages including 'F*** THE POLICE FREE DA GANG' appeared on the Met's Twitter account earlier this year.
